Graphical abstract Liquid phase exfoliation (LPE) is a promising method for synthesizing two-dimensional (2D) 2H-MoS2 due to the balance obtained in the resulting yield and quality. Improvements in the electrocatalytic activity of 2D 2H-MoS2 are typically attributed to an increased number of active sites at the plane edges. However, the conclusion need be carefully redefined in the case of LPE, because the covalent surface modification and solvent intercalation between layers can affect the electrocatalytic activity as well. In this study, bulk 2H-MoS2 was exfoliated in three typical solvents, including N, N-dimethyl formamide (DMF), formamide, and 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone (NMP), to synthesize 2H-MoS2 nanosheets. X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and Raman spectrum were used to confirm the possibility of surface and interface functionalization of the 2H-MoS2 nanosheets. Further, the effects on the electrocatalytic activity of 2H-MoS2 nanosheets were investigated mainly by density functional theory periodic calculations based on the analysis of electronic energy band structures. The results have demonstrated that 2H-MoS2 nanosheets prepared in formamide exhibit smaller average size and thickness, and higher electrocatalytic activity. The surface functionalization of the 2H-MoS2 nanosheets is indeed generated by Mo-N covalent bonds due to the presence of S vacancies. Such covalent functionalization leads to a slight decrease of energy band gap with 0.03 eV in a (3 × 3 × 1) 2H-MoS2 supercell. In contrast, the interface functionalization formed by the intercalation of solvent molecules (e.g., formamide) between layers can cause a remarkable decrease in the band gap of (1 × 1 × 2) 2H-MoS2, the phase transition from semiconductor to semimetal, higher carrier mobility, and smaller effective mass (me = 0.052 m0 ). Keywords Interface functionalization Two-dimensional nanomaterials Density functional theory calculations Electrochemistry Surface chemistry 1 Introduction Since the burgeoning applications of graphene in various research fields, two-dimensional (2D) inorganic graphene analogs have triggered intensive interest because of a wealthy of intriguing physicochemical properties beyond graphene [1–3]. In particular, 2D transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDCs), such as molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) nanosheets, can complement or even surpass graphene (zero band gap) in electronic and optoelectronic fields [4,5]. One of the unique features of 2D MoS2 is polymorphism, mainly including 2H-MoS2 (trigonal prismatic D3h, semiconducting) and 1T-MoS2 (octahedral Oh, metallic) phases, which possess different electronic structures and surface chemistry. In general, both 2H-MoS2 and 1T-MoS2 exhibit promising applications in electrochemical fields, such as electrochemical water splitting and lithium ion batteries [6,7]. Especially, highly stable 2H-MoS2 has unique properties based on its thickness. Its ultrathin planar structure provides an ideal platform to flexibly regulate electronic structures and surface features via surface or/and interface functionalization [8–10]. This will open a window for exploring some interesting physical or chemical phenomena of 2D ultrathin materials [1,4,5]. For example, 2H-MoS2 can exhibit improved electrocatalytic activity when the number and/or size of nanosheet layer decrease, even being a semiconductor with a bandgap of 1.2–1.9 eV [11–12]. Therefore, it is extremely important to figure out the relationship between structure and property, which is beneficial for reasonable design of 2D nanomaterials and exploring their potential applications. With respect to the enhanced electrocatalytic activities of 2D 2H-MoS2, the common theory purports that more edge sites are exposed as the size of layer nanosheet decreases, because its basal plane is considered inert for catalytic reactions [12–14]. However, the above conclusion could not explicitly account for 2H-MoS2 nanosheets prepared by LPE, because it neglects that there are variations in the surface features of MoS2 nanosheets synthesized via different methods, such as LPE, chemical method (e.g., lithium-intercalation exfoliation), hydrothermal methods, or chemical vapor deposition (CVD) [15–18]. In the case of LPE, surface or interface functionalization of 2H-MoS2 nanosheets cannot be avoidable during the synthesis processes. Sulfur vacancies are easily formed on the surface of 2H-MoS2 nanosheets due to thermal fluctuation, which provide organic functional groups or organic molecules with active sites for chemical or physical adsorption or “doping” [14,19]. For example, layered MoS2-thionin composites can be prepared by a combination of ultrasonication and gradient centrifugation methods, because S edges of 2D MoS2 can be modified by using thiol chemistry [8,19]. Functionalized MoS2-M(OAc)2 materials were obtained by the reaction of liquid-exfoliated 2D MoS2, with M(OAc)2 salts (M = Ni, Cu, Zn; OAc = acetate) [20]. Moreover, the covalent functionalization can enhance the stability of 2D MoS2 materials and their applicability. In our previous study, surface functionalization of 2H-MoS2 nanosheets were obtained via exfoliation of bulk 2H-MoS2 in N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF), formamide, and N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP), and a better electrocatalytic performance was achieved [21]. Among the various synthesis methods for 2H-MoS2 nanosheets, LPE is the most promising technique for low-cost mass production [22]. Especially, this method has the advantage of extreme simplicity, coupled with the fact that it produces small but high-quality exfoliated nanosheets. The resulting nanosheets can be further fabricated into films or composite materials without a third-phase dispersant (e.g., a surfactant), which can be suited to applications in different fields [23]. Herein, we synthesized 2H-MoS2 nanosheets by LPE in DMF, formamide, and NMP. Experiments and density functional theory (DFT) calculations were jointly used to prove the formation of covalent surface modification and intercalation chemistry via exfoliation solvents, and to explore their influences on electronic energy structures of 2H-MoS2 nanosheets. The study mainly gives a deep sight at the atomic scale into which factor, the covalent surface modification or interlayer engineering/functionalization, is more important for the improvement in electrocatalytic activity of 2D 2H-MoS2, in addition to the increased number of active sites on the plane edges. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals 2H-MoS2 (99.5%) was provided by Aladdin Industrial Corporation (Shanghai, China). DMF, formamide, and NMP, purchased from Tianjin Kemiou Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., were of analytical grade without additional purification. All solutions were prepared with ultrapure water (Milli-Q water, 18.2 MΩ cm) from a Millipore Milli-Q system (Bedford, MA, USA). 2.2 Characterization The structure and morphology of the 2H-MoS2 nanosheets were investigated using X-ray diffraction (XRD, PANalytical Empyrean) with Cu Kα radiation (qλ = 1.5416 Å), field-emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Hitachi S4800), and atomic force microscopy (AFM, Agilent PicoPlus). The surface properties were further studied using UV-visible (UV-vis) spectroscopy (Shimadzu UV-2450). Raman spectroscopy (Renishaw Micro-Raman system 2000) was conducted with 532-nm He-Ne laser. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, VG ESCALAB 250) was also performed. 2.3 Synthesis of MoS2 ultrathin nanosheets MoS2 ultrathin nanosheets were fabricated by LPE, according to a previously described procedure [21]. Typically, 30 mg of 2H-MoS2 powder was dispersed in 30 mL of exfoliation solvent (DMF, formamide, or NMP). After sonication for 12 h, the resultant suspension was centrifuged at 1500 rpm for 10 min to remove the bulk 2H-MoS2. The supernatant was collected and further centrifuged at 13000 rpm for 10 min, obtaining 2H-MoS2 ultrathin nanosheets. Then, 2H-MoS2 nanosheets produced via LPE in DMF, NMP, and formamide were labeled as MoS2-a, MoS2-b, and MoS2-c, respectively. 2.4 Preparation of MoS2 nanosheets/GCEs All MoS2 nanosheets were placed onto the surface of clean glass carbon electrode (GCE) for electrochemical tests. Prior to electrode modification and electrochemical measurements, the GCE was scrupulously polished in sequence with suspensions of alumina of 1, 0.3, and 0.05 μm diameter. Subsequently, the GCE was sonicated in absolute ethanol and ultrapure water for 5 min in turn to remove the possible bound microparticles. Then the electrode was dried in N2 at room temperature, and 20 μL of MoS2 ultrathin nanosheet solution (1 mg mL−1) was dropped onto the clean GCE surface. Finally, the electrode was dried at room temperature to obtain MoS2 nanosheets/GCE. 2.5 Electrochemical measurements Cyclic voltammetry (CV) and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) were performed at room temperature by a CHI 660D electrochemical work-station (Shanghai Chenhua Limited, China). A conventional three-electrode system was used, which is composed of a bare GCE (diameter of 3 mm) or modified GCE as a working electrode (WE), a platinum wire as a counter electrode (CE), and a saturated calomel electrode (SCE) as a reference electrode (RE, saturated with 3.0 M KCl). Herein, CV and EIS were performed in potassium ferricyanide solution containing 0.1 M KCl, 2.5 mM K3[Fe(CN)6], and 2.5 mM K4[Fe(CN)6]. In addition, CV measurements were then performed over a potential range from −0.2 to 0.6 V at a scan rate of 50 mV/s. EIS experiments were carried out in the frequency range from 0.01 Hz to 100 kHz with 5 mV as the amplitude. 2.6 Calculation modeling Electronic band structures and density of states were performed within the framework of density functional theory (DFT) as implemented in CASTEP [24], under the generalized gradient approximations (GGA) of Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) for electron–electron interactions [25]. The kinetic energy cutoff and the convergence threshold for energy were 400 eV and 10−6 eV, respectively. The maximal allowed force and displacement were 0.05 eV/Å and 0.002 Å, respectively. In addition, the DFT + D method within the Grimme scheme was used to consider the van der Waals forces [26]. The influences of surface-and-interface functionalization of MoS2 nanosheets on their electronic structures were investigated, using the material system of formamide and MoS2. A model of formamide-modified (3 × 3 × 1) MoS2 was used for the surface functionalization. To balance calculation accuracy and computational time, a small supercell of (1 × 1 × 2) MoS2 after intercalating formamide were used for the interface functionalization. The geometric and electronic structural calculations were simulated by periodic slab geometries with a vacuum space of 18 Å between two layers, to avoid spurious interactions between periodic images. The Brillouin zone integration was realized through k-points sampling using a (3 × 3 × 1) mesh to guarantee geometry optimization following self-consistent electronic structure calculations. The analysis of molecular orbitals was realized using Gaussian 09 program with B3LYP/6–311 + G (d, p) [27]. 3 Results and discussion As shown in Fig. 1 , compared with bulk 2H-MoS2, the average sizes and thicknesses of MoS2-a, MoS2-b, and MoS2-c obtained by LPE are drastically decreased from the microscale to the nanoscale. Interestingly, formamide used as the solvent can exfoliate bulk 2H-MoS2 into 2H-MoS2 nanosheets with smaller size and thickness, even though the surface energy of NMP better matches with that of MoS2. In principle, the concentration of 2H-MoS2 nanosheets exfoliated in NMP is bigger than that of formamide or DMF, according to the enthalpy of mixing per volume ( Δ H Mix / V ), Δ H M i x V ≈ 2 T NS σ S - σ NS 2 ϕ where σ S and σ NS are the total surface energies of the solvent and the MoS2 nanosheet, respectively. T NS is the thickness of the MoS2 nanosheet, and ϕ is the volume fraction of dispersed MoS2 nanosheet [28]. In this regard, the surface energy ( σ ) of solvent should be equal or close, as much as possible, with that of 2H-MoS2 nanosheet so that the energetic cost of dispersing the nanosheets is minimized [28,29]. The polar ( σ p ) and dispersive ( σ d ) components of σ , especially the ratio of σ p versus σ d ( σ p / σ d ), will have strong effects on the exfoliation and stabilization of 2D 2H-MoS2 [26]. As shown in Table S1, the σ p / σ d of formamide is 1.607, which is different from that of 2H-MoS2 nanosheets. Therefore, in addition to the surface energy of exfoliation solvents, there are possibly other factors, such as O2 (gas) and trace water in exfoliation solvents, which lead to such unexpected results [30]. Compared to bulk 2H-MoS2, the strongest peak for the (002) crystal plane of 2H-MoS2 nanosheets (MoS2-a, MoS2-b, and MoS2-c) becomes weak and wide, indicating the decreased thickness and size of bulk 2H-MoS2 after suffering from LPE processes. In addition, the characteristic peak exhibits a weak shift to lower 2θ values, indicating an interlayer expansion along c-axis (perpendicular to the plane). This can be explained assuming that solvent molecules act as “wedges” intercalating between nanosheet layers during LPE [31,32]. In fact, a similar behavior has been observed via molecular dynamics simulations in liquid-phase exfoliation of phosphorene [31,33]. To some extent, this phenomenon is also similar with the intercalation of metal cations in 2D layered materials [34]. Furthermore, the LeBail method was used to evaluate the interlayer expansion (Δd) of intercalation compounds. This was done by the software package Fullprof with all parameters refined by the least-squares method [35]. In addition, the pseudo-Voigt function modified by Thompson-Cox-Hastings was used as peak profile function, and the 2H-MoS2 with hexagonal crystal structure and a symmetry group of R3M (a = b = 3.166 Å, c = 18.410 Å, α = β = 90˚, γ = 120˚) was used as initial parameters. The weak expansion of the interlayer spacing along z-axis (Δd = ~0.07 Å) implies that the uptake of formamide in the van der Waals (vdW) gap of 2H-MoS2 is quite small, mainly because its uptake is easily affected by temperature and vapor pressure of formamide molecules [5]. The UV–vis absorption spectrum (Fig. S1) of 2H-MoS2 nanosheets exhibits four well-defined absorption peaks compared to that of bulk 2H-MoS2. Peaks A and B are attributed to the excitonic transitions occurring at the K/K′ points in the first Brillouin zone (Fig. S2), while peaks C and D are assigned to the optical transitions from the deep valence band to the conduction band [7]. Because the size and thickness measurements of 2H-MoS2 nanosheets rely on the effect of edges and quantum confinement, these two parameters can be quantified by the position of the peak A, λA (~670 nm), and the ratio (ExtB/Ext345) of extinction at the peak B (~610 nm) to that at the local minimum at 345 nm, respectively [22]. After the optical absorption spectra of the MoS2 nanosheet dispersions are normalized to the local minimum at 345 nm, the thickness (layer number, N MoS 2 ) and the size (L(μm)) can be calculated, according to the empirical equations [22]: (1) N MoS 2 = 2.3 × 10 36 e - 54 , 888 / λ A (2) L μ m = 3.5 Ext B / Ext 345 - 0.14 11.5 - Ext B / Ext 345 As summarized in Table S2, the MoS2 nanosheets obtained in formamide have the smallest thickness and size, that is, 5 layers and 0.17 μm, respectively. Atomic force microscopy (AFM) was also used to measure the thicknesses of MoS2 nanosheets (MoS2-a, MoS2-b, and MoS2-c), which are determined as 50, 70, and 32 Å (Fig. 3 A), respectively. Their thicknesses are in a good agreement with the calculated values (Table S2) according to Eq. (1). In contrast, the change pattern of thickness versus surface energy does not comply with the principle of screening proper exfoliation solvent that should match with MoS2 in surface energy, and leads to a high exfoliation efficiency [28,31,36]. We believe that the possible reason is the intercalation effect of solvent molecules during LPE. In addition, the peaks C and D are not dependent on the lateral dimensions and/or thickness of the nanosheets. These phenomena imply that besides the thickness, the intercalation effect of the solvent molecule can affect the electronic structure of MoS2. Raman spectroscopy was carried out to characterize 2H-MoS2 nanosheets, as a suitable nondestructive and versatile method to characterize surface structure and to study the electronic and vibrational properties of 2D materials [37]. As shown in Fig. 3 B, Raman spectra of bulk 2H-MoS2 exhibits the E2g 1 and A1g modes that are Raman actives modes located at 380 cm−1 and 405 cm−1, respectively, although in principle there are 12 normal modes of vibration existing at the center of hexagonal Brillouin zone [37,38]. The E2g 1 mode can be assigned to the in-plane opposite vibration (shear mode) of two S atoms with respect to the Mo atom, while the A1g mode is attributed to out-of-plane vibration (shear mode) of only S atoms in opposite directions. Frequently, the two modes exhibit an opposite shift in frequency, and are closely dependent on the thickness of 2H-MoS2 nanosheets. For that reason, when the number of layers (n) decreases, a blueshift occurs for the E2g 1 mode, whereas a redshift is observed for the A1g mode. In the study, both E2g 1 and A1g modes of 2H-MoS2 exhibit blueshift with the decrease of thickness when the thickness decreases, indicating the change in the lattice vibration, which is related to the intercalation of solvent molecules between the nanosheet layers [39,40]. This phenomenon has been demonstrated via molecular dynamics simulations, where the pressure given by solvent molecules in the vdW gap of 2H-MoS2 nanosheets can reach 10–50 GPa during the LPE processes [33]. In this regard, the Raman spectra (Fig. 3C) of bulk 2H-MoS2 and two-layer 2H-MoS2 nanosheets after applying a pressure of 20 GPa along z-axis (or c-axis) were obtained by DFT calculations to illustrate the changes of A1g and E2g 1 modes. The analysis of the calculated Raman spectra shows that the A1g and E2g 1 modes shift toward high frequencies after applying hydrostatic pressure. Moreover, the shift of A1g mode is more remarkable than that of the E2g 1 mode, because these modes exhibit different vibration directions (Fig. 3D). That shift is due to the special structure with a strong covalent bonding in each layer and the weak van der Waals forces between layers. As a result, the unit cell dimensions stain anisotropically as expected from a softer z-axis and harder x- and y-axes. Therefore, the high interlayer pressure due to intercalating solvent molecules can cause the blueshift in the frequencies of the Raman active E2g 1 and A1g phonon modes of 2H-MoS2. The electrocatalytic activity of bulk MoS2 before and after LPE treatments were characterized by cyclic voltammograms (CV) and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS). As shown in Fig. 4 A, compared with bulk 2H-MoS2 modified GCE (bulk 2H-MoS2/GCE), 2H-MoS2 nanosheet/GCEs show a sharp increase in redox peaks, indicating that the electrocatalytic activity of 2H-MoS2 nanosheets (MoS2-a, MoS2-b, and MoS2-c) is much better than that of bulk MoS2. Similarly, EIS measurements show that 2H-MoS2 nanosheets (especially MoS2-c) possess better interfacial electron transfer rate, according to the length of the semicircle diameter in the Nyquist plot [41]. A widely held concept in electrochemistry is that the electrocatalytic activity is determined by the active sites and electric conductivity [17]. Theoretical and experimental studies available point out that the electrocatalytic activity of 2H-MoS2 nanosheets is ascribed to the sites located along the plane edges, while the basal surfaces are catalytically inert. However, in addition to active sites, the electric conductivity is another crucial factor that affects the electrocatalytic activity, because a high conductivity ensures a fast electron transport during the electrochemical reactions. In our previous study, experimental results of XPS spectrum have proved that 2H-MoS2 nanosheets obtained in DMF, formamide, and NMP via LPE can result in the covalent functionalization of 2H-MoS2 nanosheets by Mo-N covalent bonds [21]. Surface and interface functionalization (covalent adsorption and the intercalation effect) can change the electrochemical properties of 2H-MoS2 nanosheets [12,19–21]. In the following section, we explore the influences of surface and functionalization on the electronic structures of 2H-MoS2 nanosheets via DFT calculations. DFT calculations were performed using a typical model based on formamide-modified 2H-MoS2 nanosheets, because the influences of surface/interface functionalization of 2H-MoS2 nanosheets (n-type) on the electrocatalytic activity are similar in the three solvents (formamide, DMF, and NMP). The possible binding sites for formamide are the structural defects, e.g., sulfur (S) vacancies. They were located at plane edges or in basal planes of 2H-MoS2 nanosheets, which have been experimentally confirmed via surface modification and functionalization of 2H-MoS2 nanosheets obtained by LPE [20]. Of note, many studies about covalent functionalization of 2H-MoS2 nanosheets have demonstrated that the presence of the S-vacancies in basal planes of 2H-MoS2 nanosheets is common due to energy fluctuation and unsaturated sulfur atoms [20,21,42]. Therefore, we optimized the hybrid structure of (3 × 3 × 1) 2H-MoS2 with a S-vacancy and adsorbed formamide using the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with the PBE functional, while (3 × 3 × 1) 2H-MoS2 and (3 × 3 × 1) 2H-MoS2 with a S-vacancy are viewed as a control group (Fig. 5 A and Fig. 5B). Here, the S-vacancy site was created by removing one S atom of (3 × 3 × 1) 2H-MoS2. The S-vacancy concentration is approximately 5.9% (S-vacancy percentage = percentage of sulphur atoms removed versus total sulphur atoms), which is far lower than the theoretically predicted maximum S-vacancy concentration of 11% that can maintain the surface stability [43]. For (3 × 3 × 1) 2H-MoS2 (Fig. 5A), all Mo atoms have the same Hirschfeld charge (χ), namely, χ(Mo1) = χ(Mo2) = χ(Mo3) = 0.229; on the other hand, Hirschfeld charge (χ) of the sulphur atom (S1) is −0.115. When the S1 was removed to form a S-vacancy (Fig. 5B), Hirschfeld charges (χ) of the adjacent Mo atoms became χ(Mo1) = χ(Mo2) = χ(Mo3) = 0.210, indicating of the electron transfer from the S-vacancy to the adjacent Mo atoms [7]. In (3 × 3 × 1) 2H-MoS2 with a S-vacancy, the unbonded Mo atoms, including Mo1, Mo2, and Mo3 around the S-vacancy, lead to the strong adsorption of formamide by Mo-N covalent bonds (Fig. 5C), which was confirmed by XPS spectra [21]. In addition, the charge redistribution of Mo and S atoms near the adsorption site of formamide can be obtained by comparing the difference charge density isosurface of (3 × 3 × 1) 2H-MoS2 with a S-vacancy before and after the adsorption of formamide (Fig. S3 and Fig. 5D). It was found that the interaction between 2H-MoS2 nanosheets and formamide by Mo-N covalent bonds can result in the surface polarization of 2H-MoS2 nanosheets, which can significantly change the arrangement of adsorbed water and the structure of electric double layer on the surface of 2H-MoS2 electrodes [44]. It is well known that the band gap for electronic states in crystals governs various properties of solids, such as transport properties [32,45]. Therefore, the influences of surface functionalization on the electronical structures of 2H-MoS2 nanosheets were investigated as shown in Fig. 6 . Of note, even though the calculation method underestimates the absolute band gap energy, but it is sufficiently effective to observe the trend of electronic structures before and after surface or interface functionalization. Compared with pristine (3 × 3 × 1) 2H-MoS2 (Fig. 6A), new gap states (as indicated by a red arrow in Fig. 6B) can be observed in the density of states (DOS) of (3 × 3 × 1) 2H-MoS2 after removing one S atom, indicating of the presence of the disordered regions. After formamide was adsorbed on the S-vacancy site, some additional states are shown in the DOS of (3 × 3 × 1) 2H-MoS2 (as indicated by triangles in Fig. 6C) in the range of −20 to −7.5 eV, which demonstrates a strong interaction, rather than weak long-range van der Waals (vdW) force, between formamide and (3 × 3 × 1) 2H-MoS2 with a S-vacancy. On the other hand, the DOS near Fermi level, especially around the valence-band maximum (VBM) of 2H-MoS2 (Fig. 6C), exhibit obvious overlapping with DOS of formamide (as indicated by the blue arrow), because the energy states of electron between the substrate (2D 2H-MoS2 with a S-vacancy) and the adsorbed species (formamide molecules) are close or equal in some range of electron energy states, e.g., approximately from −5 to 0 eV, where the probability of electron tunneling or transfer is higher than that in other ranges [33]. Therefore, according to the energy distribution of DOS, the energy band of (3 × 3 × 1) 2H-MoS2 with a S-vacancy allows orbital hybridization (Fig. 6C and Fig. 6D) with molecular orbitals of the adsorbed formamide in specific ranges of matched-energy states. In addition, the orbital hybridization can be confirmed by DOS of formamide before (Fig. S4) and after (Fig. 6D) adsorbing on S-vacancy of (3 × 3 × 1) 2H-MoS2; namely, the separate DOS (indicated by blue arrows in Fig. S4) become strongly overlapping states in some specific energy ranges (Fig. 6D), indicating of decreased potential barrier of electron transfer or tunneling. Such a change is also proved by electron density of surface sulfur atoms in (3 × 3 × 1) 2H-MoS2 with a S-vacancy before and after the adsorption of formamide (Fig. 6E), where the negative charge centers (blue cycles) are not well-defined as before. This change is the characteristic of electron delocalization. Because the energy of highest occupied molecular orbital (LUMO) and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (HOMO) of formamide are −0.042 eV and −7.59 eV (given in the following DFT results in Fig. 9), the interface electron transfer between 2H-MoS2 nanosheets and formamide should be performed from the VBM of 2D 2H-MoS2 to the LUMO of formamide (Fig. 6F) until both of them are equal in their Fermi levels. In order to gain a deeper insight into the influences of surface adsorption on electrocatalytic activity of 2H-MoS2 nanosheets, we further calculated electronic band structures of (3 × 3 × 1) 2H-MoS2, (3 × 3 × 1) 2H-MoS2 with a S-vacancy, and (3 × 3 × 1) 2H-MoS2 with a S-vacancy and adsorbed formamide. Three high-symmetry points of the Brillouin zone (Fig. 7 A) using the path Γ-M-K-Γ were chosen for the DFT calculations. As expected, the (3 × 3 × 1) 2H-MoS2 exhibits the feature of a direct-bandgap semiconductor which the maximum energy level of the valence band aligns with the minimum energy level of the conduction band with respect to momentum (Fig. 7B). That is, both conduction-band minimum (CBM) and VBM of (3 × 3 × 1) 2H-MoS2 are located at Γ (0, 0, 0) of the Brillouin zone. The band gap (Eg) is 1.619 eV, which is larger than that of bulk 2H-MoS2 (~1.2 eV) due to the quantum size effect. The presence of S-vacancy results in the new gap states (red plots) between the CBM and VBM of (3 × 3 × 1) 2H-MoS2 with a S-vacancy, and a reduced band gap of 0.796 eV [43]. It may be noticed that the adsorption of formamide on the (3 × 3 × 1) 2H-MoS2 with a S-vacancy does not lead to new gap states, but it further reduces the band gap from 0.796 eV to 0.764 eV [43]. The variable quantity of energy of the gap states along K ( Δ E K =0.176 eV) of (3 × 3 × 1) 2H-MoS2 with a S-vacancy and adsorbed formamide is larger than that ( Δ E K =0.156 eV) of (3 × 3 × 1) 2H-MoS2 with a S-vacancy. This difference is ascribed to the enlarged electron density after chemical adsorption. In addition, the formation of another electron wave or new states (pink curves) below Fermi level indicates a strong interaction between adsorbed formamide and 2H-MoS2 with a S-vacancy, which not only results in the electron transfer from the VBM of MoS2 to the LUMO of formamide, but also benefits the formation of delocalized electrons. In addition to the surface modification, we further investigated the influences of the solvent intercalation on the electronic structure of 2H-MoS2 nanosheets by DFT calculations (Fig. 8 ). Smaller supercells (1 × 1 × 2) of two-layer 2H-MoS2 nanosheets before and after the intercalation of formamide (Fig. 8A and Fig. 8C) were used to lower the calculation cost and comprehensively consider the interaction between the nearest-neighbour formamide molecules. The electronic band structure (Fig. 8B) of the two-layer 2H-MoS2 shows a non-degenerate conduction band minimum at K-point of the Brillouin zone, and a feature of indirect-band-gap semiconductor, where the maximum energy of the valence band occurs at a different value (Γ → K) of momentum to the minimum in the conduction band energy. In addition, the calculated energy gap of two-layer 2H-MoS2 is 1.55 eV, which is slightly lower than the experimental value (1.6 eV), because in general GGA tends to underestimate the absolute band gap energy of semiconductors [25]. However, the calculated energy gap of two-layer 2H-MoS2 is larger than that of bulk 2H-MoS2 due to the quantum size effect [37]. After the formamide molecules intercalated between the nanosheet layers, the electronic band structure of two-layer 2H-MoS2 nanosheets show a character of semimetal with a Fermi level crossing both the valence-band maximum and the CBM (Fig. 8D). Such significant decrease in the band gap of 2H-MoS2 nanosheets was not observed in experiments (Fig. S5), mainly because the amount of solvent molecules between vdW gap of 2H-MoS2 can strongly affect the electronic structure (Fig. S6). Furthermore, there is a small amount of formamide molecules between vdW gap of multi-layer MoS2 nanosheets, which has been proved by the weak interlayer spacing expansion of ~ 0.07 Å according to XRD results (Fig. 2A). Therefore, when a large amount of formamide molecules could intercalate into vdW gap of 2H-MoS2, it would lead to the obvious changes of electronic energy band, even the phase transition, which is similar with the processes of Li+-intercalation and exfoliation for synthesizing 1T-MoS2 [7,34]. The change in the electronic band structure is ascribed to the electron injection of 2p and 2 s orbitals of formamide into the 4d band of Mo atoms. Of note, the electronic band structure of the MoS2-formaide hybrid materials is different from the pure 1T-MoS2. Electron motion in the latter is performed from CB to VB without a transfer barrier (Fig. S7), whereas for the former electron transfer from CB to VB even along the low-barrier path of K → Γ or Γ → Γ still requires the addition of phonon. Additionally, the carrier mobility of (1 × 1 × 2) 2H-MoS2 after interacting formamide is significantly improved, because its electronic band structure near the Fermi level is changed from the localized states to the extended states, that is, from the partially flat band at the Γ point (Fig. 8B) to Dirac cone-like structure (Fig. 8D) [44]. We also computed the effective mass (me ) of electron associated with the valence-band maximum of (1 × 1 × 2) 2H-MoS2 before and after the intercalation of formamide at the Γ point. It was found that the effective electron mass of (1 × 1 × 2) 2H-MoS2 after interacting formamide was 0.052 m0 , much smaller than that (me = 0.35 m0 ) of pristine two-layer 2H-MoS2 (all masses were calculated with the PBE functional). The results demonstrate that (1 × 1 × 2) 2H-MoS2 after interacting formamide will exhibit a higher carrier mobility than pristine two-layer 2H-MoS2, possibly because of the reinforcement of the electron–electron correlations of infinite S-Mo-S framework after interacting formamide [46]. Orbital hybrid processes between formamide and (1 × 1 × 2) 2H-MoS2 were investigated by the analysis of the corresponding DOS and PDOS (Fig. 9 ). The DOS at the Fermi level is set as zero for pure (1 × 1 × 2) 2H-MoS2. After suffering from the intercalation of formamide between vdW gap, (1 × 1 × 2) 2H-MoS2 exhibits gap states (with a shoulder peak) near the Fermi level in its DOS. The DOS of (1 × 1 × 2) 2H-MoS2 was mainly composed of p and d orbitals, regardless there was intercalation or not. Thereinto, the conduction band minimum is mainly composed of spatially spread spherical d orbitals, while the valence band maximum is mainly composed of p orbitals (Fig. 9A and C). Based on the principle of energy-matched DOS, the interface intercalation leads to the electron transfer and orbital hybrid processes between LUMO of formamide (Fig. 9B) and CB of (1 × 1 × 2) 2H-MoS2. In addition, for the intercalation complex, the HOMO (-7.59 eV) and nearest-neighbour orbitals (-9.48 eV) of formamide allow the orbital hybridization with p and d orbitals of (1 × 1 × 2) 2H-MoS2, which result in the broadening and overlapping of DOS (Fig. 9C). The intercalation effect of solvent molecules leads to the localized states, which can reduce the band gap of 2H-MoS2 nanosheets. Furthermore, the solvent intercalation between van der Waals gap of 2H-MoS2 nanosheets will enhance the electronic coupling ( H DA ∊ ) and the effective density of electronic states near the Fermi level ( ρ M E F ), which are beneficial for the interfacial electron transfer, according to the rate constant ( k f ) for nonadiabatic interfacial electron transfer [47], (3) k f = 2 π ρ M E F h π λ k B T 1 / 2 ∫ ∞ - ∞ H DA ∊ 2 × e x p - λ + E app - E o e - ∊ 4 λ k B T f ∊ d ∊ Where k B is the Boltzmann constant, Î» is the nuclear reorganization parameter, H DA ∊ is the electronic coupling between the donor and acceptor sites, h is Planck’s constant, ρ M E F is the effective density of electronic states near the Fermi level ( E F ) of the electrode, E app is the applied potential and E° is the reduction potential of the redox species, ∊ is the energy of a particular electrode level relative to the Fermi level, e is the elementary charge, and f ∊ is the Fermi Dirac distribution of occupied states. In general, the solvent intercalation (Fig. 8 and Fig S6) has more profound influences in the electronic structure of 2H-MoS2 nanosheets than the surface functionalization (Fig. 7). 4 Conclusions In this study, we investigated the surface and interface functionalization of 2H-MoS2 nanosheets synthesized by LPE in DMF, NMP and formamide, and their influences on electrocatalytic activity. Among the three solvents, MoS2 nanosheets obtained in formamide exhibited a smaller average size and thickness, and a higher electrocatalytic activity. The covalent functionalization and the intercalation effect of solvent molecules (e.g., formamide) exist during LPE process. Our DFT calculations have demonstrated that the intercalation effect of formamide, when compared to the covalent surface functionalization, plays more important role in reducing the band gap and improving electrocatalytic activity of 2H-MoS2 nanosheets. Thus, in addition to the increased active sites at plane edges, the intercalation effect of exfoliation solvent should be considered as another important factor affecting the electrocatalytic activity of 2H-MoS2 nanosheets synthesized by LPE. coredata.dc:description: Liquid phase exfoliation (LPE) is a promising method for synthesizing two-dimensional (2D) 2H-MoS2 due to the balance obtained in the resulting yield and quality. Improvements in the electrocatalytic activity of 2D 2H-MoS2 are typically attributed to an increased number of active sites at the plane edges. However, the conclusion need be carefully redefined in the case of LPE, because the covalent surface modification and solvent intercalation between layers can affect the electrocatalytic activity as well. In this study, bulk 2H-MoS2 was exfoliated in three typical solvents, including N, N-dimethyl formamide (DMF), formamide, and 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone (NMP), to synthesize 2H-MoS2 nanosheets. X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and Raman spectrum were used to confirm the possibility of surface and interface functionalization of the 2H-MoS2 nanosheets. Further, the effects on the electrocatalytic activity of 2H-MoS2 nanosheets were investigated mainly by density functional theory periodic calculations based on the analysis of electronic energy band structures. The results have demonstrated that 2H-MoS2 nanosheets prepared in formamide exhibit smaller average size and thickness, and higher electrocatalytic activity. The surface functionalization of the 2H-MoS2 nanosheets is indeed generated by Mo-N covalent bonds due to the presence of S vacancies. Such covalent functionalization leads to a slight decrease of energy band gap with 0.03 eV in a (3 × 3 × 1) 2H-MoS2 supercell. In contrast, the interface functionalization formed by the intercalation of solvent molecules (e.g., formamide) between layers can cause a remarkable decrease in the band gap of (1 × 1 × 2) 2H-MoS2, the phase transition from semiconductor to semimetal, higher carrier mobility, and smaller effective mass (me = 0.052 m0 ).
coredata.dc:title: Improving electrocatalytic activity of 2H-MoS2 nanosheets obtained by liquid phase exfoliation: Covalent surface modification versus interlayer interaction
